info.author: Matthew Seal
info.description:
allset
======

A small python utility for auto-completing ``__all__`` and binding
sub-modules in ``__init__.py`` files.

How to Use
----------

Add these lines to the top of your ``__init__.py``.

::

    import allset
    allset.set_all_submodules(globals())
    allset.bind_all_submodules(globals())
    del allset

Now you can reference any sub-module with ``import mysubmodule`` or
``from mysubmodule import SubModClassDef``. Additionally, the
``from mymodule import *`` will work as though you specified all
sub-modules in ``__all__`` manually.

What's it do?
-------------

-  ``set_all_submodules`` sets up you ``__all__`` variable by
   auto-detecting the files and sub-modules in the current directory.
-  ``bind_all_submodules`` takes the submodules found in
   ``set_all_submodules`` and applies them to the current namespace.
info.name: allset
info.summary: Generates dynamic bindings for module imports
info.html_description:
A small python utility for auto-completing __all__ and binding sub-modules in __init__.py files.

How to Use

Add these lines to the top of your __init__.py.

import allset
allset.set_all_submodules(globals())
allset.bind_all_submodules(globals())
del allset

Now you can reference any sub-module with import mysubmodule or from mysubmodule import SubModClassDef. Additionally, the from mymodule import * will work as though you specified all sub-modules in __all__ manually.

What’s it do?

  • set_all_submodules sets up you __all__ variable by auto-detecting the files and sub-modules in the current directory.
  • bind_all_submodules takes the submodules found in set_all_submodules and applies them to the current namespace.
